alert.note: Alert for South and East Jackson, Larimer, North and Northeast Grand, Northwest Boulder Counties Above 9000 Feet; South and Southeast Grand, West Central and Southwest Boulder, Gilpin, Clear Creek, Summit, North and West Park Counties Above 9000 Feet; West Jackson and West Grand Counties Above 9000 Feet (Colorado) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Winter Weather Advisory issued January 01 at 11:38AM MST until January 03 at 12:00AM MST by NWS Boulder
info.description: ...LONG DURATION WINTER STORM FOR MOUNTAINS...SNOW AND MIXED PRECIPITATION DEVELOPS OVER THE PLAINS THIS EVENING... .A storm system will move into the Desert Southwest today and then track to the Four Corners area late tonight. On Monday, it will move across Colorado and then push into the Central Plains by Monday night. This track will support development of widespread snow, as well as some light freezing precipitation across portions of the plains. In the mountains, ongoing heavy snow in the far northern tier of mountains will taper off late this morning. After a lull through the rest of he day, snow will redevelop this evening and continue through Monday and Monday evening before tapering off again late Monday night. Hazardous and slow travel conditions can be expected during this period. Across the foothills, I-25 Corridor, and adjacent plains, areas of snow will be developing this evening, with the most persistent snow spreading to the northern border area through early Monday morning. Behind that, areas of light freezing drizzle or rain will be possible, leading to icy road conditions. Precipitation will trend to almost all snow by mid to late afternoon Monday, and there may be an increase in snowfall rates as well especially on the northeastern plains into Monday evening. Travelers across the foothills and plains will encounter hazardous travel conditions starting this evening and continuing through Monday and Monday evening. ...WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM 7 PM THIS EVENING TO MIDNIGHT MST MONDAY NIGHT... * WHAT...Snow expected. Total snow accumulations between 6 and 11 inches. * WHERE...Rabbit Ears Pass, Rocky Mountain National Park and the Medicine Bow Range, and The Mountains of Summit County, the Mosquito Range, and the Indian Peaks. * WHEN...After a lull this afternoon, more snow will redevelop this evening and continue through Monday evening. * IMPACTS...Travel will be very difficult due to heavy snow accumulations.
info.instruction: Slow down and use caution while traveling. The latest road conditions for Colorado can be obtained by calling 5 1 1 or by going to www.cotrip.org. If you must travel, keep an extra flashlight, food, and water in your vehicle in case of an emergency.
